comment.author: 23682063@N08
comment._content: The street looks narrow. I think that building on the far left is still there, but I don't recognise the others. Probably torn down and the street widened.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: @ Japester68 - these old telephone poles are very helpful in dating old photos. The style changed often to cope with rapidly changing technology and increased demand. See www.telephonecollecting.org/lightpoles.htm . I reckon these were pre-1900.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The WH Paling Music store at 356 George St. was demolished about 1891, see www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3863063363/ So this photo is about 1890 (like a lot of the Henry King collection).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is an almost identical Henry King photo taken five minutes later - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=31273 .

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Of the businesses which I've managed to identify, all appear to have been long stayers at these addresses thru the 1880s and into the 1890s...going on digitised newspapers name search hits, Griffiths & Weaver, Stock & Station Agents, appear to have operated in Sydney in the period ca. 1875-1894...per this 'Notice of Removal' (column 2) they appear to have moved to the building on the corner of Hunter and George Streets in ca. May 1877 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13396932 ; Smith & Mannell appear to have moved to 298 George St in early 1880 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article64973541 ... per various digitised newspaper hits, they appear to have remained trading there until ca. early 1894 ; there was a fire at Lloyd & Collins on 30/7/1887, but they appear to have refurbished and continued to trade afterwards - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13646776 ; T.T. Jones & Son appear to have moved to 316 George St in 1882 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article861774 ; and were still there in April 1899 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14226127 ; notably, the photographer (Henry King) was also at 316 George St during the 1880s, though I suspect he might have moved in ca. 1890...you can see his sign in the five minutes later pic which Beachcomber has tagged...here's a report on a hailstorm which hit this part of town in December 1889 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13753859 ; The temporary fix on Lloyd & Collins' awning is interesting...possibly a makeshift repair put up after the 1887 fire...or maybe it was put up after this 1889 hailstorm...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Now this is interesting...over at State Records NSW they have an Excelsior Photo Co pic taken in October 1883, which shows this stretch of George St...it was taken up past 330 George St, looking back this way (the pic is titled 'Peapes and Shaw's shop, George Street - showing wooden parapet'...I can't work out how to bring up the url)...this State Records NSW pic enables us to identify Peapes & Shaw's building at 324-328 George St (per this notice the building might have been undergoing a re-fit in 1883, see column 1 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13545021)...you can just make out the name on the parapet of 324-328 if you look at the purl version of this Tyrrell Collection pic...per various digitised newspaper hits, Peapes & Shaw appear to have occupied 324-328 George St from ?the early 1880s thru to mid March 1889, after which they moved across the road to 311 George St (notice towards top of column 3) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13717334 ; so provided that the sign on 324-328 reflected the reality on the ground, there's a good possibility that this pic was taken prior to or soon after Peapes & Shaw's move in mid March 1889...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: This is interesting...I've just noticed that instrument maker, etc Angelo Tornaghi had his business at 298 George St at the time this pic was taken...you can see his name on the windows on level 1 (ie. above Smith & Mannell). Per various digitised newspaper hits, Tornaghi appears to have been at 298 George St during the later 1880s and early 1890s (so he can't help us pin down the year in which this pic was taken)...By the 1880s, Tornaghi had established his reputation as one of the leading instrument and clock makers in NSW, and by then he'd successfully provided clocks for a number of public buildings both in Sydney and in the country. In 1887 Tornaghi won the contract to fit the clock and bells for the GPO tower. However before long he had issues with hanging conventional bells in the tower and opted instead for tubular bells, contrary to the provisions of the contract. In the end, following delays and controversy, and unable to win support for his tubular bells, Tornaghi was dumped, a new contractor was appointed and a clock and bells were ordered from Britain...eventually being installed from about July 1891 and then officially set in motion by Lady Jersey in September 1891. It's probably not quite correct to suggest that Tornaghi was responsible for the vacant space in the GPO clock tower which we see in this pic, but he certainly had something to do with it! Here's a brief item on Tornaghi - www.powerhousemuseum.com/insidethecollection/2010/08/scie...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
51979177@N02
comment._content: It's often a good idea to start with the obvious things - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63621464

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: ...and sometimes it's an even better idea to look more thoroughly in the first place! Per this SMH notice, Griffiths & Weaver moved to the newly erected Norwich Chambers in Hunter St on 1 November, 1886 (column 5, 4th from top) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28351289 ; in my initial trawling thru the digitised newspapers I'd seen the Hunter St address on G&W's post November 1886 adverts and had assumed that this involved the offices above Hume's chemists on the corner of Hunter and George Sts...ho hum... Here's a SMH advert from later in November 1886 which confirms that G&W were by then past tense at the corner of Hunter and George Sts (column 2, 4th notice in 'Offices to Let') - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13621441 Here's an 1885 SMH item on Norwich Chambers, then under construction - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13595372 ; So, unless I've overlooked something else (always a possibility!) I'd say we're looking at January-November 1886. I'd say that G&W would have removed the signage from their office above Hume's at the corner of Hunter and George Streets either when they moved, or very soon afterwards...and given the American Studio appears to have vanished off the radar at 310 George St after 1885, maybe we're looking at earlier in 1886 rather than later (by which time the American Studio's sign might have been removed)...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: PS - The bells were evidently hoisted up into the GPO tower in July 1891...the clock faces appear to have been fitted in July-August 1891...see my update at www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2554622065/
